bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, September 28, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker, September 28, 1720, reporting that "throughout the Country a plentifull Crop is made" which he hopes will not affect prices for tobacco. He had an agreement with Captain Russel to make use of some of Russel's tobacco in payment for "Some Barbados goods" but it proved unnecessary. He sends a bill of exchange from Sam Heath, and hopes that Russel will bring him "some of the right sort of the ale" on his next voyage.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, September 28, 1720

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. 28. 1720
Mr. Edwd. Tucker

div1.p:
I hope before now Yor. admiral
& his little [fleet? ] are safe wth. You, This may
Serve to advise You that throughout the Country
a plentifull Crop is made wch. we hope will
have no Influence upon the last Years Tobo.
Markett The best allay to our large
Crop It is superlatively good—

Capt. Russel was so generous to leave
me a liberty to make use of some of his
Tobo. in paymt. of Some Barbados goods I
had bought, but my own held out so well I med
-led wth. none of his.

Herewth. comes a first bill of Exche.
[draw] n on yourself by Sam. Heath for £20
wch. I lett him have cash for to answer some
of Yor. occasions & desire my Accot. may be
credited with it. [Pray] let my respect for Mr.
Russell not be forgot, and I hope he'll not forget
to bring me in some of the right sort of the ale
the next [ . . . ]

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 55-56. This page in the letter book is extremely difficult to read because of bleed through of ink from the writing on the reverse of the page, and some holes.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Captain Giles Russell commanded the Brimpton, a vessel which sailed often from Weymouth to Virginia from at least as early as 1711. (Survey Report 9711, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
